awd_titl_txt: IRES Track I: Development of Global Scientists and Engineers by Collaborative Research on Reliability-Aware IC Design
awd_abstract_narration:
This IRES Track I project will support collaborative research to develop new algorithms and techniques for reliability-aware physical design and optimization of VLSI systems. U.S. students will be trained through collaborative research between two teams -- UCR's VLSI System and Computation Research Lab (VSCLAB) and Tsinghua University's Design Automation Lab.   Each year five American students will participate in the IRES program. IRES students will spend 10 weeks (one academic quarter) at UCR and 10 weeks at Tsinghua University, China. Specific IRES collaborative research, education and culture activities are planned to expose U.S. undergraduate or graduate students to the global engineering education and research environment through US-China academic collaboration. The collaborative educational and research activities will provide unique training, mentoring, networking and intellectual development opportunities for students at UCR, which is a growing and Minority Serving Institution. This project thus provides a unique opportunity to contribute to diversity in the U.S. technical workforce. Such international engagement will benefit the students' entire careers and make them more competitive and competent in their careers as scientists and engineers.  Furthermore, building long-term connections with top-tier engineering schools like Tsinghua University will help U.S. scientists and engineers maintain competitiveness in the long term.  Finally, the joint research will strengthen existing computer engineering research and education programs, and broaden the collaborative research work at UCR.

 The IRES collaborative project will produce important research advances through joint development of efficient algorithms and design methodologies to address the grand challenges of reliability-aware physical design and optimization of VLSI systems. The researchers will work on the most severe and challenging aspects of verification and design problems of silicon CMOS based integrated systems in current and coming 10nm/7nm nodes: modeling, analysis of long-term interconnect reliability effects such as electromigration (EM), time-dependent dielectric breakdown (TDDB), bias temperature instability (BTI) and reliability-aware physical design and optimization. The mutual interests and complementary knowledge, and established trust between the two research teams is critical for the success of the student training, mentoring and the proposed joint research project. The education and research activities of this joint project consist of following activities: student training, mentoring and intellectual development via pre-trip preparation and on-site visits; new courses and seminar development for proposed research topics; joint research projects and student supervision and publications; promoting and nurturing diverse cohorts of U.S. students; evaluation for continuous improvement of the program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this program is to initiate a new collaborative research program with the Design Automation Lab at Tsinghua University, Beijing, China, to jointly develop new algorithms and techniques for reliability-aware physical design and optimization of VLSI systems.

On the education sides: following 18  students participated the IRES programs directly (exceed the proposed 15 students)


1. Winson Bi is  a Computer Engineering (CEN) student (2019 cohort)

2. Carson Welty is a Computer Science student (2019 cohort)

3. Cole Pivonka is a Computer Engineering (CEN) student (2019 cohort)

4. Sheriff Sadiqbatch was Ph.D. student, who was also the team leader and mentor for the undergraduate students during their travel to China in 2019.

5. Michael O?dea is a  computer engineering student (2020 cohort)

6. Jonathan Clarke is a computer engineering student (2020 cohort)

7. Ally Thach  (female) is a computer science student (2020 cohort)

8. Christian Campos (Hispanic) is a computer science student (2020 cohort)

9. Abraham Park is a computer engineering student (2020 cohort)

10. Ainaz Estiri (female) is a  Computer Science student (2021 cohort)

11. Cuong (Chris) Thi is a Computer Engineering student (2021 cohort)

12. Isabella Santiago (female,Hispanic) is a Computer Science student (2021 cohort)

13. Karsten Fields is a Computer Science student (2021 cohort)

14. Ruby Franco Martinez (female, Hispanic) is a computer science student (2021 cohort)

15. Srikar Voleti is a Computer Science student (2021 cohort)

16. Thomas Henningson is a Computer Science student (2021 cohort)

17. Vy Vo  (female) is a Computer Science student (2022 cohort)

18. Thomas Piibe is an Electrical Engineering  student (2022 cohort)


In additional to those IRES students, several Ph.D. students in my research lab also participated in the mentoring and collaborative research work and were the major contributions for their research outcome.
For the first three years,  After the summer visit, program evaluation was  performed by outside company called The Mark (previously called SmartStart) via student survey.  

The external evaluation finds in 2019 that the IRES program indeed significantly improved student desire and ability to work with scientist from other countries. Also, all three undergraduate students have a very high interests in pursuing a career in STEM field (before the program, one student shared that they he did not have any interest in graduate school). Similar findings were observed for 2020 survey.  


In 2020, the external evaluation finds that the IRES program indeed significantly improved student interest from fair to high in both Two of the three undergraduate respondents increased their interest from fair to high in both pursuing a graduate level degree in a STEM field and pursuing a career in a STEM field, after participating in IRES. Also majority students have good or extensive desires  to collaborate with other researchers and develop scientific relationship.  


The external evaluation in 2021 finds that ?consistent across all three years of the project, improvements occurred in all goal areas with increases in student?s knowledge and skills on subjects related to EM aging models, simulation techniques and new EM-aware optimization techniques, collaboration skills and communication skills?. Further this year survey found that ?respondents also had statistically significant increases in these skills and knowledge. The project also helped increased participant?s likelihood of pursuing graduate degrees and careers in STEM.?  The evaluation report from the Mark is attached.
Following are major research tasks finished, which are partially supported by this award.


(1) Dynamic reliability management for multi-core processor based on deep reinforcement learning

(2) Long-term reliability management for multitasking GPGPUs

(3) Reliable power grid network design framework considering EM immortalities for multi-segment wires

(4) Machine Learning Based Online Full-Chip Heatmap Estimation

(5) Hotspot-Aware Task Mapping for Lifetime Improvement of Multicore System using Deep Reinforcement Learning

(6) Full-Chip  Power Density and Thermal Map Characterization for Commercial Microprocessors under Heat Sink Cooling

(7) GPU based Parallel Binary Hyperdimensional Computing For Fast  Classification

(8) Hardware-Efficient Approximate Logarithmic Multiplier with Reduced Error

(9) Post-Silicon, Machine Learning Based Real-Time Full-Chip Thermal Tracking

(10) Learning based spatial power characterization and full-chip power estimation for commercial TPUs

(11) Real-time full-chip thermal tracking: a post-silicon, machine learning perspective

The PI's team has published 7 conference papers and 3 journal papers supported by this award. On the education side, totl 18 IRES (17 undergraduate students, 1 graduate students) students directly participated this program (more than 15 proposed target). All of them come from UCR. Among them, we have 4 female students, 3 Hispanic students. 


In additional to those IRES students, 11 Ph.D. students participated this project as mentors for the IRES students and received supports from this award. Those students also participated the proposed research works. Those students  include Dr. Han Zhou,  Dr. Zeyu Sun, Dr.Dr. Sheriff Sadiqbatcha.  Dr. Wentian Jin, Dr. Jinwei Zhang, Dr. Shuyuan Yu,  Mahila Tasnim, Yibo Liu,  Mohammadamir Kavousi, Chinmay Raje, Jincong Lu.
